qas.question: How did Murdoch describe critics of his newspaper?

answers.text: "snobs" who want to "impose their tastes on everyone else"

qas.question: What did Murdoch and Mackenzie say in defense of The Sun?

answers.text: they are "giving the public what they want"

qas.question: Who is one critic of The Sun?
What was the focus of Pilger's reporting in one issue of The Daily Mirror?

answers.text: the genocide in Pol Pot's Cambodia

qas.question: What distinction does one single edition of The Daily Mirror hold?

answers.text: the only edition of the Daily Mirror to ever sell every single copy issued throughout the country

context: Murdoch has responded to some of the arguments against the newspaper by saying that critics are <a0_0>"snobs" who want to "impose their tastes on everyone else"<a0_0/>, while MacKenzie claims the same critics are people who, if they ever had a "popular idea", would have to "go and lie down in a dark room for half an hour". Both have pointed to the huge commercial success of the Sun in this period and its establishment as Britain's top-selling newspaper, claiming that <a1_0>they are "giving the public what they want"<a1_0/>. This conclusion is disputed by critics. <a2_0>John Pilger<a2_0/> has said that a late-1970s edition of the Daily Mirror, which replaced the usual celebrity and domestic political news items with an entire issue devoted to his own front-line reporting of <a3_0>the genocide in Pol Pot's Cambodia<a3_0/>, not only outsold The Sun on the day it was issued but became <a4_0>the only edition of the Daily Mirror to ever sell every single copy issued throughout the country<a4_0/>, something never achieved by The Sun.
